title: 109_s4029
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nursing Education and Quality of Health Care Act of 2006". Congress acknowledges the significant role of the nursing workforce in healthcare, with a projected need for 1.2 million new nurses by 2014. Schools of nursing face challenges in accepting qualified applicants due to a shortage of faculty. Nurse faculty members are aging, and nurses play a crucial role in preventing medication errors. Employing more highly educated nurses can reduce patient mortality rates and prevent adverse events. SEC. 3. Rural Nurses Training Grant Program added to the Public Health Service Act to improve patient outcomes by training more highly educated nurses. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for educating nurses in rural areas through distance learning. Funds will be used for technology infrastructure, video conferencing, faculty training, and clinical site support. Analyses will be conducted annually after grants are awarded. The Secretary will collect and analyze data on the number of nurses in the United States to track rural nursing trends. A report on the nursing workforce will be generated annually, and funding is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. SEC. 4. NURSE FACULTY DEVELOPMENT. Amends the Public Health Service Act to include a Nurse Faculty Development Program. The Secretary will award grants for nurse faculty development projects, including recruitment programs, scholarships for RNs to pursue graduate education in nursing education, additional education for nurses with graduate degrees to become faculty, and accelerated doctoral programs for nursing faculty positions. The Nursing Education and Quality of Health Care Act of 2006 aims to address the nurse faculty shortage by facilitating entry into nursing faculty positions, developing online continuing education courses, practice teaching opportunities, research internships, and fellowships for nursing students. A report will be submitted to Congress addressing the causes of the shortage and making recommendations to increase and retain nurse faculty members. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. In fiscal years 2007 through 2011, amendments allow more than 10 percent of traineeships for individuals in doctoral degree programs to address nurse faculty shortage. SEC. 822 of the Public Health Service Act amends Part C of title VIII to focus on developing the rural nursing workforce. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to increase nursing opportunities in rural communities, including pipeline programs, nurse mentor programs, and training for guidance counselors. The program aims to support web-based healthcare workforce development, increase capacity of accelerated nurse programs in rural communities by adding faculty and clinical training sites, and provide financial incentives. The program aims to provide financial incentives, such as loan forgiveness and tuition assistance, for nurses practicing in rural areas. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. SEC. 6. NURSING AND THE QUALITY OF HEALTHCARE. Title VIII of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a program linking nursing education with quality outcomes. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for demonstration projects that enhance nursing practice quality and patient safety. Eligible entities include schools of nursing, nursing centers, academic health centers, and others approved by the Secretary. Partnerships with other eligible entities are required for grant eligibility. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for healthcare quality improvement activities, including improving patient safety, timeliness of care, effectiveness of care, equity, efficiency, and patient-centeredness. Priority will be given to entities that will carry out these activities. The Secretary will prioritize entities implementing initiatives in professional nursing education to enhance patient safety through evidence-based practice and quality improvement strategies. This includes developing partnerships between nursing schools and healthcare facilities to educate nurses in various areas and providing scholarships for advanced nursing education. Integrating quality and safety competencies into nursing education programs by disseminating patient safety education content to nurse faculty administrators and developing web-based modules for continued nurse faculty education. The Secretary will award grants for continuing education in nursing, including web-based modules on patient safety and systems for dissemination. Grants will also support data collection to study the benefits of nursing education levels on quality improvement efforts. The Nursing Education and Quality of Health Care Act of 2006 aims to evaluate the impact of nursing education levels and certification status on patient outcomes and cost savings. This includes analyzing quality indicator data, collaborating with state health departments, and demonstrating cost savings from projects. A report to Congress on the program's results is required within two years of enactment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the program. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the program under this section for fiscal years 2007 through 2011.
